title: So, imagine that your jungler really pisses you off
body:
You play top Aatrox and you lose your lane against Akali and her jungler. It's really bad and you are forced to hug your turret. When you die another time, your jungler Kayn flashes at your opponents, damages two creeps with his Q and deals some damage to Akali, but she gets away. Kayn lasthits(without nuking the wave) a couple of creeps and you do not like it. It looks like he is going to push it and even though he doesn't, you get mad at him.

You follow him through his jungle for 13 minutes, unsuccessfully trying to lasthit his jungle to the point where the game ends, constantly reminding Kayn that you hope he likes the consequences of his actions, without using difect insults.

You get manually reviewed by Riot support. What is going to be your punishment?

replies.body: Did you really follow your jungler around for 13 minutes because he didn't manage a successful gank for your lane after you fed relentlessly? I'd say two weeks at a minimum.

Why is hate speech worse than runining a match?

Because ruining a game once just shows you had a temper tantrum - if it only happens once, it's literally one game out of millions that was ruined. Using hate speech shows that that word is a part of your vocabulary, and there are only two reasons you'd use words like that:

1) You know you were using that word, and used it with the intent to hurt.
2) You used it when really upset, which indicates you use it often enough in your day to day life that it is a fallback for you when you're not thinking.

Either of which shows a degree of prejudice. I'm more willing to forgive someone for having a bad temper than for being prejudiced.

Except this is a discussion of what WE THINK. Your opening question was an inquiry about what we THINK a punishment would be for a specific set of actions. So this it is not irrelevant TO THIS DISCUSSION. Additionally, it's not irrelevant as Riot built their discipline system partially off of data of what people reported for. So what we, as a community, consider acceptable IS relevant to any discussion of player behaviour.

That being said, I don't want to punish thought. Think whatever you want during a game. I frequently think my allies are terrible or that x person is a troll. I just show enough self-restraint to not TELL those people I think that of them.

What I want to punish for is action. Particularly actions that are driven by a **pattern of intent**. A person throwing a temper tantrum and doing something once does not show a pattern of intent. If that person throws a temper tantrum in every game they play that they start losing, different story. Or if they do it every time a surrender vote fails. Or if every time they go 0/3 they start trolling, again different story. Those all show **patterns of Intent**.

A person having racist vocabulary be a big enough part of their thought process that they fall back on it when they want to insult someone shows a pattern of intent as well. I guarantee you no matter how upset I am or how much I want to insult someone, I'm never going to use the N word. Why? Because it is not a part of my day to day vocabulary. There are a lot of words that are - absolutely. And when upset and wanting to insult someone, I'm gonna fall back on those because they're the words that are I think of most commonly when upset at someone.

Even taking it a step further, the cultures you talk about who use those words in a positive way... they won't fall back on them in a moment of anger either. Why? Because they use those words POSITIVELY. An African American who uses the N word among his friends as a term of endearment isn't going to fall back on it as a way to insult someone who pisses him off because the word isn't an insult to him. It's a term of endearment. So again... if you are falling back on racist terminology when you want to insult someone, that shows that - to you - those words ARE insults and they ARE a part of your regular thought process.

Goddammit, you want to do it, don't you?

You could also use those words in a non-offensive context, which is punishable by the way and to me you look like someone who would support this policy, but that's my personal judgement and it might not be the case. Still, it's what Riot considers to be right.

And crushing the idea that having n-word as the part of your daily vocabulary automatically makes you a racist, this is my most commonly used insult by a mile, due to discussing topics like **this** in more lenient and tolerant communities, without resorting to using it as an insult.

Oh, and hurting people based on the fact that they are racist is not civilised.

Oh no, I don't condone HURTING anyone. However, I don't consider a ban from a video game to be 'hurting' someone. If you cannot treat people with respect, you should lose the privilege of dealing with people in leisure. Playing LoL is a privilege, not a right.

As to your comment about 'completely destroys the match', yes, it does. However, everyone has bad days, and sometimes people do bad things when they're upset. If it's a one-off occurrence, I believe the loss + the miserable day they've suffered to be sufficient punishment. If it's a pattern, then they need to lose their privilege to play.

Twitches can result in you making weird typoes or bashing keys by accident, absolutely, but they won't result in you typing coherent words. So again, that's not a justification.
